text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mandate of the United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA) is defined in Security Council resolutions 1401 (2002), 1662 (2006) and 2626 (2022), and renewed by its subsequent resolutions, including the most recent resolution 2777 (2025), which extended the mandate of the Mission until 17 March 2026.

As mandated by the Security Council, UNAMA will continue to promote peace and stability in Afghanistan, including: coordinating and facilitating enhanced cooperation and coherence in the financial resourcing and delivery of humanitarian and basic human needs assistance that support strengthened resilience; coordinating efforts with donors and other stakeholders to reduce risk and increase accountability, transparency and effectiveness in the use of aid; supporting efforts, including essential services provision and economic recovery, to create the conditions for self-reliance and stability for the Afghan population; assessing the explosive ordnance threat and coordinating mitigation measures to enable humanitarian and development initiatives; providing outreach and good offices to promote dialogue between Afghan stakeholders, the region and the international community to promote inclusive and responsive governance, and providing advice on inclusive national and local consultative mechanisms, and confidence-building measures; promoting responsible governance and the rule of law; engaging with all stakeholders on the promotion and protection of human rights, including the rights of women and girls; supporting regional cooperation; and supporting existing mechanisms to improve the overall security situation in Afghanistan, including regional and international efforts to prevent and address the illicit trade in and destabilizing accumulation of small arms and light weapons and their diversion in Afghanistan and the region.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which the Mission contributes, is to create the conditions for peace and stability, with foundations established for the promotion of inclusive and responsive governance and functioning and accountable institutions, as well as a coherent and sustainable path towards the economic and social conditions for self-reliance.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:

(a)	Coordinate with international donors, organizations and partners in addressing the humanitarian and basic human needs of vulnerable Afghans. It will partner with the United Nations country team to support economic development and increase donor confidence for greater basic human needs support, as emphasized in the independent assessment on Afghanistan requested by the Security Council in its resolution 2679 (2023), and to implement the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development with a focus on the goals of the Pact for the Future, particularly on climate financing, poverty alleviation and upholding the principles and values of the UN Charter. To that end, it will support resource mobilization to enable humanitarian efforts, essential services, livelihoods restoration, support to the private sector, economic development and mitigation of the dangers of explosive remnants of war. UNAMA will engage with the de facto authorities and other stakeholders to facilitate the support of the United Nations, international financial institutions and other international and national partners to the socioeconomic recovery of Afghanistan from the severe economic contraction;

(b)	Provide outreach and good offices, including facilitating dialogue between Afghan political actors and stakeholders, regional stakeholders and the wider international community. UNAMA will use its convening platforms at the national and subnational levels to facilitate engagement and cooperation between the de facto authorities, civil society, youth, communities, women-led organizations and other stakeholders on governance and policy issues, such as inclusion, participation and responsiveness to constituency concerns. It will maintain support for promoting the participation of women and minorities in all spheres. UNAMA will also continue to identify further entry points for engagement with the de facto authorities for the benefit of all Afghans, including through the proposed United Nations roadmap and comprehensive approach for Afghanistan. In addition, the United Nations and international partners will monitor and report on developments related to the rule of law and conduct analysis relating to the political economy. The Mission will provide technical and analytical support to United Nations agencies, humanitarian partners, and continue to engage with civil society, the media, communities and counterpart institutions of the de facto authorities, in compliance with the sanctions set out in relevant Security Council resolutions related to anti-money-laundering and counter-terrorism financing;

(c)	Advise stakeholders on and promote respect for civil, political, economic, social and cultural rights, particularly human rights issues pertaining to children affected by armed conflict; discrimination against women and girls; the treatment of detainees and the prevention of torture and ill-treatment; human rights defenders and civic space; and the promotion of accountability for human rights violations. In addition, UNAMA will continue to integrate human rights and gender mainstreaming as cross-cutting issues in mandate implementation. The Mission will promote and support gender equality, women’s and girls’ empowerment and the participation and leadership of women in public life and at all levels and stages of decision-making. It will also partner with the United Nations country team to promote the protection and fulfilment of the rights of women and girls and the implementation of Security Council resolution 1325 (2000) on women, peace and security and successive resolutions;

(d)	Support peace and stability in Afghanistan through consultations and by utilizing its convening power for dialogues with political stakeholders. The Mission will use existing mechanisms to advance regional cooperation on economic development and security to help foster a regional environment conducive to sustainable peace and stability. In addition, it will propose and support regional approaches to issues, such as the return and reintegration of refugees and internally displaced persons, combating illicit drugs and trafficking, addressing the illicit accumulation and trafficking of small arms and light weapons in Afghanistan and the region, and reducing the illegal economy and its impact. It will also coordinate explosive ordnance threat mitigation measures to enable the safe delivery of humanitarian and basic human needs initiatives;

(e)	Intensify its work to implement the United Nations Strategic Framework for Afghanistan, 2023-2025, which was extended to 2027, in line with the humanitarian-development-peace nexus, by engaging with the de facto authorities, civil society and the media to facilitate the transition of society from conflict to peace and removing explosive remnants of war. UNAMA will contribute to the goal of reduced dependency on aid, prioritizing UN assistance in critical sectors such as banking, trade and economic reform. The Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General/Resident Coordinator/Humanitarian Coordinator will ensure a coherent approach to United Nations humanitarian and basic needs programming for the benefit of the Afghan people. The Mission will streamline the delivery, oversight and reporting of aid provided in Afghanistan, in alignment with the Strategic Framework and in partnership with the de facto authorities, civil society and international partners. UNAMA will also enhance collaboration on aid architecture and risk management practices.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

Advancement of a political process involving the de facto authorities and other national stakeholders within and outside Afghanistan, as well as the international community to improve the situation of Afghans, including efforts for improved inclusiveness and responsiveness of governing entities, and support the creation of conditions that could eventually lead to the reintegration of Afghanistan into the international community in accordance with relevant Security Council resolutions;

Progressive compliance by all parties with international humanitarian law and human rights obligations, with improved accountability for human rights violations and abuses that builds confidence in such mechanisms and between the population and the de facto authorities;
Ongoing accurate reporting to the international community on the evolving situation in Afghanistan and its implications for international peace and security;

Sustained local, regional and international support to meet humanitarian and basic human needs and economic development, and to create an environment conducive to socioeconomic recovery in Afghanistan.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the Mission cooperates with international and regional entities and supports constructive dialogue between the relevant Afghan stakeholders, regional actors and the international community that is focused on the rights and socioeconomic progress of the Afghan people.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, UNAMA engages with the United Nations country team to strengthen the repositioning of the United Nations development system and to deliver more effectively and efficiently in line with the 2030 Agenda, the Pact for the Future, the Sustainable Development Goals and the humanitarian-development-peace nexus. UNAMA and the United Nations country team collaborate closely on issues related to governance, the rule of law, human rights and gender, focusing on policy issues and good offices. With the evolving context in Afghanistan, the Mission’s work also supports the delivery of humanitarian response and meeting basic human needs through the restoration of essential services, livelihoods and community systems, in line with Inter-Agency Standing Committee recommendations. The Mission supports the removal of explosive ordnance, the delivery of risk education and the provision of victim assistance to enable humanitarian and basic human needs activities. It collaborates with various stakeholders to explore new aid approaches targeting economic promotion and recovery. UNAMA also leads the coordination of an overall risk management approach of the United Nations in Afghanistan, including mitigating the risk of aid diversion, and engages with the United Nations country team to increase efficiency gains and effectiveness of operations by sharing services and premises. In addition, the Mission coordinates on specific issues with the United Nations Regional Centre for Preventive Diplomacy for Central Asia to provide good offices and expert advice on confidence-building measures in the region that contribute to stability in Afghanistan.
With regard to external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

(a)	The de facto authorities will remain in control of the territory of Afghanistan. However, political, security, human rights, legal, socioeconomic and humanitarian uncertainties will continue. The likely continuation and furthering of restrictive policies will present challenges for the full reintegration of Afghanistan into the international community;

(b)	Lack of international recognition, and, to an extent, domestic legitimacy of the de facto authorities due to questions about lack of representation and inclusion, the dissonance between their ideology and international norms and standards, and the continuous absence of a constitution and promulgation of repressive decrees especially towards women and minority groups, will significantly challenge engagement with domestic, regional and international stakeholders on the future of Afghanistan;

(c)	The security situation will remain uncertain, with the likelihood of continued attacks by Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant-Khorasan Province against the de facto authorities and the international presence, activities of anti-Taliban armed opposition groups and dynamics related to the presence of regional and international foreign terrorist fighters and their access to illicitly accumulated small arms and light weapons, with an impact on access and physical security for the Mission, as well as development and humanitarian actors;
(d)	Relations between Afghanistan and some of its neighbours will remain tense due to unresolved security issues, threats of terrorism, and migration and water management issues;

(e)	Civilians, including those working as humanitarians and supporting basic human needs, will continue to face the threats of explosive ordnance, including those from improvised explosive devices and explosive remnants of war;

(f)	Enduring threats, such as terrorism, organized crime and illicit trafficking, including in narcotics, small arms and light weapons, and resource competition, will continue, with threats emerging from issues such as land rights and disenfranchisement of minorities, population outflow, returnees, unemployment and the impact of evolving regional dynamics, as well as vulnerability to the adverse impact of climate change, ecological changes and natural disasters, which may heighten the risks of local conflicts over land, water and other resources;

(g)	The economy and human development will remain adversely affected by the continuing impact of non-recognition and donor sensitivities, the severe restrictions by the de facto authorities on national female staff working for the United Nations and non-governmental organizations and the limitations of the de facto authorities to reinvigorate the economy and reduce poverty, with the resumption of development funding depending on the de facto authorities meeting international norms, especially related to human rights protection, including for women and girls;

(h)	In a context where funding is diminishing and mobilizing additional resources is increasingly challenging, the United Nations is expected to demonstrate increased complementarities and efficiencies in humanitarian assistance and recovery support. This includes focusing on meeting basic human needs by maintaining essential services and preserving community systems;

(i)	As viable alternatives for large-scale legitimate financial transactions remain unavailable, the United Nations will continue to rely on and incur the costs associated with the cash importation facility of the United Nations Secretariat, managed by United Nations Headquarters.

The Mission integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results. For example, in its engagement with the de facto authorities and political stakeholders, UNAMA continues its advocacy for the full and meaningful participation of women in political processes at all levels. The Mission continues to support the implementation of Security Council resolutions 1325 (2000) and 2493 (2019), particularly on gender equality, the empowerment of women and girls and their human rights.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, UNAMA will implement its revised strategy plan focusing on: (a) increasing outreach projects and activities with persons with disabilities in communities to foster engagement; (b) reinforcing an organizational culture that supports the inclusion of persons with disabilities; (c) advancing disability inclusion in strategic planning and management, knowledge and information management, staff training and career development; and (d) promoting workplace accessibility and enabling the performance of functions.
Evaluation activities

The audit by the Office of Internal Oversight Services (OIOS) of UNAMA's emergency preparedness and management of cost recovery arrangements and an internal evaluation of UNAMA's outreach activities were completed in 2024 and have guided the proposed programme plan for 2026. In response to the internal evaluation findings highlighting the critical role of outreach activities in mandate implementation, UNAMA will expand its outreach engagements to foster dialogue between Afghan stakeholders, including de facto authorities. This will support efforts to achieve rights-based stability and promote the full reintegration of the Afghan State into the international community.
Programme performance in 2024
Creation and maintenance of space for dialogue among diverse Afghan constituencies, amid increasing restrictions on the Afghan population and the narrowing media and public space

Space for women, youth, and ethnic and religious minority groups was enabled through UNAMA’s engagement with Afghan stakeholders to support their agenda for dialogue with the de facto authorities, including their political and economic participation and empowerment. This was a result of UNAMA’s continued countrywide consultations, including its engagement with the de facto authorities and other stakeholders on the protection of human rights in Afghanistan, including for women and girls, to understand their position and advocate for an articulated socioeconomic, political and policy agenda supported by the de facto Cabinet and its leadership in Kandahar; and the facilitation of outreach and community engagements with the de facto authorities, religious leaders, youth, civil society and business actors. The Mission also engaged with the political opposition and former government officials.

Based on stakeholder engagements, UNAMA identified areas of common interest for targeted action, such as counter-narcotics, climate change and enabling the private sector, including microfinance and women’s entrepreneurship. UNAMA engaged with a wide range of stakeholders, including broad consultations with business women and men and participation of technical experts in the small group on alternative livelihoods as part of the working groups on counternarcotics and the private sector under the ‘Doha process’. UNAMA also fostered dialogue between the international community and the de facto authorities, resulting in enhanced aid coordination. The Afghanistan Coordination Group held key meetings on funding, private sector development and humanitarian-development-peace nexus, while the High-Level Coordination Forum broadened its focus from humanitarian aid to coordination for basic human needs assistance.

Nevertheless, ongoing restrictions on the media and civic space by the de facto authorities continued to particularly impact women media workers and women civil society actors, as well as United Nations national female personnel, significantly impacting the Mission’s ability to conduct outreach.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 1).
Table 1 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Enhanced UNAMA-facilitated dialogues between diverse Afghan constituencies and the de facto authorities to discuss good governance principles and improve community relations, as well as to promote international community engagement with the de facto authorities on international norms and principles
Despite significant restrictions on women, continuous engagement with Afghan constituencies, the facilitation of outreach meetings, contributed to maintaining some space for diverse voices

Some space for diverse voices was created and maintained despite continued restrictions on the Afghan population, especially women, as a result of the Mission’s continuous engagement with the de facto authorities and other Afghan constituencies, and facilitation of outreach meetings

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: rights-based stability in Afghanistan – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the Mission maintained regular engagement with the de facto authorities, other national stakeholders and the international community on human rights, rule of law, governance and inclusion issues. Given ongoing restrictions on women and girls’ enjoyment of their rights and amid shrinking civic space, UNAMA continued advocacy with the de facto authorities to reverse their restrictions on women, civil society and media, as well as to engage other national and subnational stakeholders, including through the UN-convened meetings of Special Envoys on Afghanistan and subsequent working groups.

In 2026, the Mission will maintain engagement with the de facto authorities on overarching priorities, particularly the situation of vulnerable groups, including women and girls, as well as ethnic and religious minorities, and efforts on accountability for human rights violations by de facto authorities. This work is expected to contribute to the level of international assistance to meet humanitarian and basic human needs, efforts towards compliance with international human rights and humanitarian law obligations, and a more conducive environment for inclusive governance.
Progress toward the objective and the target for 2026 is presented in the performance measure below (see table 2).
Table 2 – Performance measure

table_content.text:
Regular United Nations engagement with the de facto authorities, other national stakeholders and the international community for sustained support to meet humanitarian and human needs, as well as compliance by relevant de facto authorities with international human rights and humanitarian law obligations
Regular United Nations injection of cash for humanitarian assistance, in coordination with the Central Bank and other partners
Regular subnational outreach meetings and facilitated community relationship-building and engagement with de facto authorities

Regular United Nations engagement with the de facto authorities, non-Taliban figures and those from different ethnic groups and geographical regions, to advocate for inclusive governance as well as support for the establishment of mechanisms at the national and subnational levels for inclusive governance.
Provision of support to the development of a structured policy dialogue for confidence-building between Afghan stakeholders and the international community
Continued efforts towards an inclusive  and responsive governance and pursuit of a political path for confidence-building between Afghan stakeholders and the international community
Continued efforts towards an inclusive, representative, participatory and responsive governance model, including dialogue between diverse Afghan constituencies and the de facto authorities

A responsive and consultative governance model is identified, including through political consultations among the de facto authorities, other Afghan stakeholders and the international community, facilitated by the Mission

children.text: Result 2: supporting efforts towards the full reintegration of the Afghan State with the international community – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

The Mission supported the second and third UN-convened Meetings of Special Envoys for Afghanistan in Doha, Qatar, in February and June-July 2024, with the de facto authorities participating in the latter and Afghan civil society representatives in dedicated sessions at both meetings. UNAMA subsequently supported the establishment of working groups on the private sector and counternarcotics as part of confidence-building measures.

The Mission will renew efforts to facilitate dialogue between Afghan stakeholders, including actors from all strata of society inside Afghanistan. It will continue to support the United Nations country team and international partners with institutionalizing the monitoring of delivery of principled basic human needs assistance into verifiable reporting mechanisms for the accountability of the United Nations Strategic Framework.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 4).
Table 3 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Facilitation of more coherent, coordinated and structured international engagement, including the convening of two meetings of the Special Envoys for Afghanistan in Doha in February and June/July and the subsequent launch of the working groups on counternarcotics and the private sector.

Continued facilitation of increased coherent, coordinated and structured international engagement aimed at an Afghanistan reintegrated into the international community and meeting international obligations
Increased coherent, coordinated and structured international engagement with tangible steps towards an Afghanistan reintegrated into the international community and meeting international obligations

children.text: Result 3: Strengthened economic and social resilience in Afghanistan – Proposed programme plan for 2026

The Mission will continue its efforts to increase basic human needs programming through the coordination of United Nations agencies and resource mobilization with donors while maintaining advocacy to continue resourcing critical humanitarian needs. It will pursue increased aid dialogue with the de facto authorities to promote a conducive regulatory and operational environment for the private sector and aid organizations.
Lessons learned and planned change

A lesson for the Mission was the importance of strengthening the private sector and encouraging assistance towards livelihoods, as this approach reduces humanitarian needs, strengthens the resilience of Afghans, and paves the way for economic stability.    In applying the lesson, the Mission will strengthen its engagement with the private sector, including through the ‘Doha Process’ Private Sector Working Group and regular consultations with private sector representatives. The Mission will further capitalize on the strategy defined in the United Nations Strategic Framework for Afghanistan and engage non-donor member states to align their private sector support with a holistic private sector support strategy that promotes the resilience of Afghan communities and equitable growth.
Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 4).
Table 4 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Strengthened resilience of Afghan communities as a result of a strategic shift from a predominantly humanitarian response to increased funding for basic human needs
Strengthened aid dialogue with the de facto authorities enabling a more conducive regulatory and operational environment for the private sector and aid organizations

text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026

children.text: 1.	Total resource requirements
Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 6 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 7 – Human resources
a	One post is funded at 50 per cent and cost-shared with the Development Coordination Office.
b	Includes one P-5, one P-4, one NPO and one LL positions approved as general temporary assistance.

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for UNAMA amount to $124,463,100 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for civilian personnel costs ($87,958,000) consisting of salaries, common staff costs and danger pay for the deployment of 1,049 posts and positions (1 Under-Secretary-General, 2 Assistant Secretary-General, 1 D-2, 5 D-1, 25 P-5, 54 P-4, 53 P-3, 4 P-2, 111 Field Service, 121 National Professional Officer, 1 National General Service staff, 557 Local level and 114 United Nations Volunteers), inclusive of the abolishment of 117 posts of which 38 posts for KJSO will be abolished effective 1 October 2026, the proposed establishment of 18 new posts and 3 new international United Nations Volunteers positions, and the proposed conversion of nine national United Nations Volunteers from extrabudgetary resources; the cost of one military observer ($23,700); and operational costs in the amount of $36,481,400.

The decrease in requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable to reduced requirements for civilian personnel, owing mainly to the abolishment of 117 posts and the application of a higher vacancy rate for international staff, offset by higher requirements for United Nations Volunteer costs owing to a lower vacancy rate and higher entitlement costs, as well as the proposed establishment of 18 new posts.  The decrease in requirements is offset in part by increased requirements for operational costs, attributable primarily to additional requirements for: (a) construction of a central warehouse for more efficient space management and for the improvement of the wastewater treatment plant and the compound facilities including for security upgrade; and (b) acquisition of safety and security equipment as well as the replacement of prefabricated accommodations and equipment, and engineering supplies required for the general maintenance of the compounds and to support the planned minor projects.
Figure I – Distribution of proposed resources for 2026 – (Number of posts/thousands of United States dollars)
Vacancy rates

The table below outlines the proposed vacancy rates for 2026, which takes into account the 2024 average deployment and the actual vacancy rate as at 31 March 2025. This is in line with the policy guidance provided to improve the accuracy and consistency of the vacancy factors applied in the proposed budget for 2026 and to ensure that proposed vacancy rates are based, as much as possible, on actual rates. A vacancy rate of 50 per cent has been applied in the calculation of costs for the proposed establishment of new posts and positions, or posts and positions proposed for reassignment.
Table 8 – Vacancy rates
(Percentage)
a	Includes General Service and Local level staff.
2.	Staffing requirements
For 2026, a number of efficiency-driven reconfigurations and optimizations to the structure and staffing of UNAMA are proposed, resulting from efforts focused on:

(a)	Streamlining the Field Office configuration in the northern region, through the closure of Maimana and Pul-e Khumri provincial offices, with the mandate delivery in these areas to be the covered by a roving capacity from the Mazar-Sharif regional office, resulting in the proposed abolishment of 19 posts, the reassignment of 6 posts and positions, and the redeployment of 14 posts to various field offices and the Security Section in Kabul.

(b)	Restructuring the security communications architecture for greater operational efficiency: it is proposed to create a Remote Security Operations Centre in Kabul which would enable radio networks to be monitored remotely, reducing the requirement to operate physical security operation centres in the field leading to the proposed abolishment of 21 Field Radio Operators (Local level) posts.  The Centre is proposed to be constituted with 21 Field Security Radio Operators (Local level) through the continuation of the 4 existing posts in Kabul, and the redeployment of the remaining 17 Field Radio Operators (Local level) posts from the field offices.

(c)	Transitioning of client missions of KJSO to the Regional Service Centre in Entebbe, Uganda  (RSCE): In view of the termination of the mandate of UNAMI on 31 December 2025, it is the intention of the Secretariat to transition the peace operations supported by the KJSO to the RSCE by the end of the UNAMI liquidation process which will end in September 2026. In line with this plan, the current budget contains the proposed abolishment of 38 KJSO posts funded from UNAMA, effective 1 October 2026;

(d)	Further optimization of staffing resources to address capacity gaps in key mandated areas and repurposing resources in view of evolving priorities, ensuring that posts and positions are aligned to the functions performed, and that they are only retained after critical review for continuing needs. These gaps and competing priorities were discussed in several senior leadership meetings before and during budget preparation, and also through further consultation with Headquarters.

In view of the low percentage of female national staff within the Mission, UNAMA is continuously undertaking efforts to address challenges that prevent the attainment of gender parity through capacity-building of women. The national United Nations Volunteers play a critical role in the mission's activities both in substantive and mission-support sections, and are essential for achieving and maintaining UNAMA's mandate, including by integrating Afghan women's perspectives in all areas of work and enhancing the Mission’s capacity to reach local communities and the most vulnerable groups.  In line with the efforts to continue to improve the gender balance in the Mission’s staffing, and taking into account the prospects of shrinking extrabudgetary resources, it is proposed that the existing nine female national United Nations Volunteer positions currently funded from extrabudgetary resources be converted to regular budget funding in 2026, to continue to support programmes of work of components across the Mission. The conversion provides some element of assured continuity in this flagship initiative which supports the advancement of women’s involvement in society and support UNAMA’s gender parity efforts to employ and empower young professional Afghan women who would otherwise be struggling to find professional purpose in their lives after graduation.
The cost efficiencies to be achieved for 2026 are as follows:

children.text: For 2026, the proposed staffing complement reflects a net decrease of 87 posts and positions, as a result of the following changes:
•	Abolishment of 117 posts (2 P-5, 1 P-4, 2 P-3, 1 P-2, 21 Field Service, 10 National Professional Officer and 80 Local level), inclusive of 38 posts abolished in KJSO effective 1 October 2026;
•	Establishment of 21 posts and positions (1 P-4, 1 P-3, 3 National Professional Officer, 13 Local level) and 3 international United Nations Volunteer);
•	Reassignment of 12 posts and positions;
•	Redeployment of 39 posts; and
•	Conversion of 9 positions from extrabudgetary funding.
These changes are detailed by organizational unit in the sections below. Annex II to the present report provides the organizational charts.

children.text: The Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Afghanistan provides strategic leadership to the political, human rights and development/humanitarian coordination-related work of the United Nations in the country. The Special Representative serves as Head of Mission and is responsible for the executive management of the Mission’s resources and administration. She is supported by the Front Office.
Proposed organizational changes – Table 11 – Human resources: Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Afghanistan

table_content.text: Chief of Section, Conduct and Discipline

children.text: The following changes are proposed for 2026:
Front Office of the SRSG:

Redeployment of one post of Chief of Section, Conduct and Discipline (P-5) to Kabul, from Kuwait, effective 1 January 2026, in view of the closure of UNAMA Support Office in Kuwait; and to enhance oversight and coordination with key stakeholders and client missions, taking into account that UNAMA accounts for more than half of the allegations processed by the Unit

Establishment of one Associate Protocol Officer (National Professional Officer) and one Assistant Coordination Officer (National Professional Officer) in combination with the proposed abolishment of the two posts of Administrative Assistant (Local level) to strengthen the protocol capacity of the Office, which requires dedicated protocol and advisory support at a higher degree of expertise and responsibility in order to provide effective engagement support to the Head of Entity. The Associate Protocol Officer will be responsible to support the Office in managing formal engagement with the de facto authorities on UN privileges and immunities and host country obligations, coordinating high-level meetings, and managing administrative tasks to ensure timely resolution of sensitive issues and enhanced Mission compliance with host country protocols and procedure. The Assistant Coordination Officer will support the Office’s high-level political engagement through liaison, coordination and contextual advisory functions, including maintenance of working relationships with de facto officials, diplomatic missions and civil society actors; preparation of correspondences and background materials; provision of general administrative support; and advise on cultural, religious and political sensitivities to ensure effective engagement in a politically complex environment.

Human Rights Service: Redeployment of one post of Human Rights Assistant (Local level) from the Kabul field office to support the work of the Service on issues related to detention monitoring and the prevention of torture and ill-treatment in prisons and places of detention;

Gender Advisory Unit: Reassignment of one position of Facilities Management Assistant (international United Nations Volunteer) as Gender Affairs Officer (international United Nations Volunteer) from the Acquisition Management Unit to enhance the capacity of the Unit to effectively mainstream gender equality as a cross-cutting issue throughout the mandate implementation and support the advancement of the implementation of the women and peace and security agenda, in line with Security Council resolution 2727 (2024) and related resolutions;

Security Section: Changes to the staffing structure in the Security Section are proposed to ensure effective resource management and efficiency of the day-to-day administrative needs of the Section and in the context of the restructuring of the Mission’s field security operations centre. UNAMA has reviewed its security communications architecture and in line with recommendations from assessments undertaken, proposes to create a central Remote Security Operations Centre in Kabul. Currently, the Mission operates physical security operations centre in each field location, with 46 Field Security Radio Operators providing security communications support nationwide, Under the remote modality, security communication operations will be consolidated in Kabul. which will centrally monitor and operate remote field radio networks. With the implementation of the remote centre, the number of physical security operation centres in the regions would be reduced, leading to the abolishment of 21 Field Security Radio Operator (Local level) posts across the various field offices. To this end, it is further proposed that the centre be constituted through the continuation of 4 existing posts in Kabul and the redeployment of 17 Field Security Radio Operator (Local level) post from the field offices (10 from the regional offices and 7 from the provisional offices. The following changes in the Section are therefore proposed for 2026:

Reassignment of two posts from Kabul Field Office, comprising: one post of Security Coordination Officer (P-3) as Administrative Officer (P-3) to reflect adjustments to the roles and responsibilities currently undertaken by the post in view of the need to have dedicated administrative capacity at the appropriate level; and one post of Fire Safety Officer (Field Service) as Security Officer (Field Service) in the Security Investigations Unit to provide critical support to security investigation and incident response;

Abolishment of one post of Security Officer (Field Service) and establishment of one post of Administrative Assistant (Local level) to strengthen the administrative and financial oversight within the Security Section and to promote the nationalization of functions;

Abolishment of two posts of Security Officers (Field Service) in view of the streamlining of operational functions, it was determined that the functions can be absorbed by the existing capacity within the Section;

Abolishment of six posts of Field Security Guard (Local level), based on a review of security requirements at the UN Air Terminal in Kabul, which assessed that the functions of the posts can be discharged by existing staff within the Section;

Abolishment of two National Professional Officer posts of Assistant Security Officer and Associate Training Officer, in combination with the proposed establishment of two Local level posts, one Field Security Assistant and one Training Assistant, as the functions have evolved, and it was determined that the tasks currently being performed can be effectively carried out with a lower-level skill set;
Establishment of one post of Administrative Assistant (Local level) to support budget execution, procurement processing, and contract management;
Establishment of one position of Security Officer (international United Nations Volunteer) to support the coordination of security-related activities and administrative processes;
Redeployment of 17 Field Security Radio Operator (Local level) posts from the field offices to constitutes the Remote Security Operations Centre;
Redeployment of one Field Security Guard (Local level) from Kabul field office to support operational requirements.

Redeployment of one position of Security Logistics Officer (international United Nations Volunteer) from Herat field office to support the Section needs with respect to the coordination of security logistics, inventory management, and transportation services; and

Conversion of two positions of Local Security Assistant (national United Nations Volunteer) from extrabudgetary resources to regular budget funding, as referred to in paragraph 30, to provide effective administrative, logistical and operational support to the Crisis Coordination Centre and to serve as the first security point of contact to all UN staff requiring security assistance.
Table 12 – Afghanistan Team of the Asia and the Pacific Division of the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs
a	One post is funded at 50 per cent and cost-shared with the Development Coordination Office.

The Afghanistan Team of the Asia and the Pacific Division of the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs (1 D-1, 1 P-5, 1 P-4, 1 P-3 and 1 General Service (Other level)) will continue to provide backstopping to the Mission, including the provision of operational support, assistance in identifying and prioritizing critical strategic objectives in line with the Mission’s mandate and political needs, and engagement with Member States and other key regional and international partners.

children.text: The Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General (Political Affairs) advises the Special Representative of the Secretary-General on political issues and the dynamics affecting the implementation of the mandate of the Mission and manages the political pillar. The Deputy Special Representative supports the implementation of the mandate through the provision of regular analyses of the political situation in the country and the region, by: (a) liaising with the international community, diplomatic community and NGOs in Afghanistan on political issues; (b) coordinating political priorities within the Mission and with United Nations Headquarters; and (c) providing good offices and outreach, particularly in the areas of political stability and regional cooperation.
Table 14 – Human resources: Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General (Political Affairs)

Redeployment from Strategic Engagement Advisory Unit
Redeployment from Strategic Engagement Advisory Unit

children.text: The following changes are proposed for 2026:

Front Office: Reassignment of one post of Associate Political Affairs Officer (National Professional Officer) as Coordination Officer (National Professional Officer) to the front office of the DSRSG /Resident Coordinator/Humanitarian Coordinator to enhance the coordination role of the Office in engaging with the de facto authorities at the highest levels to ensure coherence, collaboration, efficient resource allocation, and to provide political support for the optimal humanitarian and basic human needs outcomes in line with the responsibilities laid out in the operative paragraph 5 (a) and (b) of UN Security Council resolution 2626 (2022);
Political Affairs Service:

Abolishment of one post of Senior Civil Affairs Officer (P-5) due to the current restrictive operating environment and limited opportunities to support local communities, which are now primarily spearheaded at the local level through UNAMA field offices;

Redeployment of the three posts from the Strategic Engagement Advisory Unit comprising of one Senior Political Affairs Officer (P-5), one Political Affairs Officer (P-3) and one Associate Political Affairs Officer (National Professional Officer) with a view that the functions previously undertaken by the Strategic Engagement Advisory Unit can be integrated within the Political Affairs Service. The integration aims to reinforce the Mission’s comprehensive approach to engagement with the de facto authorities; provide timely advice on political dynamics and policy directions of the de facto authorities, enhance strategic and operational engagements with other Afghan political stakeholders; and to enhance collaboration with the field offices on sub-national political issues;

Reassignment of one post of Associate Judicial Affairs Officer (National Professional Officer) as Assistant Programme Management Officer (National Professional Officer) in Kandahar field office, in response to the need to have dedicated capacity support to the mine action programme at the regional level;
Abolishment of two posts of Political Affairs Assistant (Local level), following a review of current workload arrangements; and

Conversion of three positions of Associate Political Affairs Officer (national United Nations Volunteer) from extrabudgetary resources to regular budget funding, as referred to in paragraph 30, to monitor, support and report on activities related to political inclusion and security related activities by the de facto security forces, facilitate engagement with different actors, and to support data collection and management as the basis for political economy analysis;
Liaison Office in Islamabad: Abolishment of one post of Protocol Assistant (Local level), following a review of the workload of the Office;
Strategic Engagement Advisory Unit: Redeployment of the three posts (1 P-5, 1 P-3 and one National Professional Officer) to the Political Affairs Service, as described in paragraph 38(b)(ii) above.

Joint Analysis and Reporting Section: Abolishment of one post of Political Affairs Assistant (Local level) as the post has been vacant and the functions can be adequately covered by the existing staff within the Section.

The Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General/Resident Coordinator/Humanitarian Coordinator is responsible for maintaining links with the United Nations country team as part of the role of Resident Coordinator and Humanitarian Coordinator. The Security Council, in paragraph 5 (a), (b), (i) and (j) of its resolution 2626 (2022), mandated the Deputy Special Representative to coordinate and facilitate the provision of humanitarian assistance and financial resources to support humanitarian activities; coordinate international donors and organizations in relation to basic human needs; coordinate the overall risk management approach of the United Nations in Afghanistan; and coordinate explosive ordnance threat mitigation measures in support of humanitarian and development initiatives.
Table 16 – Human resources: Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General/Resident Coordinator/ Humanitarian Coordinator (development pillar)

table_content.text: Reassignment from Office of the DSRSG (Political Affairs)

children.text: The following proposals are made for 2026:
Front Office:

Establishment of one post of Political Affairs Officer (P-3) to strengthen the Mission’s capacity on Climate, Peace and Security, and lead on: (i) engagement across UNAMA’s field offices on climate security risks and environmental peacebuilding/local peace initiatives related to climate change; (ii) data collection, reporting, and analysis; (iii) engagement with nongovernment organizations, Afghan academia and civil society to support analysis and outreach, focusing on the inclusion of Afghan women and youth; and (iv) support for joint United Nations action and coordination with the United Nations country team in a politically sensitive environment;

Establishment of one post of Assistant Coordination Officer (National Professional Officer) to support UNAMA’s work on Climate, Peace and Security, particularly in coordinating engagement with the de facto authorities;

Reassignment of one post of Political Affairs Officer (National Professional Officer) as Coordination Officer (National Professional Officer) from the Office of the DSRG (Political Affairs) to serve as a key interlocutor between the Office and the de facto authorities on issues such as access, the operating and regulatory environment of aid operations and related security issues and advocacy on UN privileges and immunities;

Continuation of three general temporary assistance positions of Senior Programme Management Officer (P-5), Associate Programme Management Officer (National Professional Officer) and Data Analysis Assistant (Local level) established to support the mine action programme in UNAMA. The UNAMA Mine Action Unit supports the implementation of the Mission’s mine action programme in line with Security Council resolution 2626 (2022), paragraph 5 (c); provides technical expertise and advice to Mission leadership and relevant stakeholders on mine action and engage with national mine action authorities, the United Nations country team and the humanitarian team to advocate for mine action.  In this context, it is proposed that the three temporary positions be continued, to advance the UNAMA mine action objectives in the most effective, cost-efficient and transparent manner; and

Continuation of  one general temporary assistance position of Coordination Officer (P-4) to continue to undertake research and analysis, triangulating information on the delivery of assistance in Afghanistan, and facilitate engagement and negotiation with the de facto institutions around operational challenges in delivering humanitarian and basic human needs assistance to the people of Afghanistan, as well as advocating with the de facto authorities for rights, inclusion, equity, transparency and accountability in aid delivery.

Risk Management Coordination Section: Establishment of one post of Programme Officer (P-4) to provide specialized expertise in the area of Anti-Money Laundering and Countering Terrorist Financing activities (AML/CTF) activities. The establishment of the post will enhance the United Nations system’s capacity in Afghanistan in addressing the growing risks associated with money laundering and terrorism financing activities through the implementation of robust safeguards and compliance with international standards on AML/CTF, maintain donor confidence and protect integrity and accountability of United Nations programmes.

children.text: The following proposals are made for 2026:

Procurement Unit: Abolishment of one post of Procurement Assistant (Field Service), following an internal review of the Mission’s mode of operations which has shifted towards greater utilization of information and communications technology tools in the mission;
Field Technology Section:

Reassignment of one post of Associate Information Systems Officer (National Professional Officer) as Assistant Programme Management Officer (National Professional Officer) in the Kabul Regional Office in response to the need to have dedicated capacity support to the mine action programme at the central region level;
Abolishment of one post of Information Systems Assistant (Local level) as the functions of the post can be absorbed by existing capacity in the Section; and

Conversion of one position of Associate Information Management Assistant (national United Nations Volunteer) from extrabudgetary resources to regular budget funding, with reference to paragraph 30, to support the implementation of the file classification scheme and records management.

Human Resources and Training Section: Reassignment of two posts of Administrative Assistant (Local level), one from Maimana and one from Pul-e Khumri field offices, as Human Resources Assistant (Local level), to enhance the Section’s capacity to address critical staff queries, support recruitment and onboarding activities, data analysis and reporting;

Acquisition Management Unit: Reassignment of one position of Facilities Management Assistant (international United Nations Volunteer) as Gender Affairs Officer (international United Nations Volunteer) in the Gender Advisory Unit.

children.text: The following proposals are made for 2026:
Office of the Chief of Supply Chain and Service Delivery Management: Abolishment of one post of Administrative Assistant (Local level) following a review of the workload;
Aviation and Movement Control Section:

Abolishment of six posts, comprising four of Movement Control Assistant (1 Field Service and three Local level) and two of Air Operations Assistant (Local level), following a review of the workload of the Section; and

Conversion of one position of Air Operations Assistant (national United Nations Volunteer) from extrabudgetary resources to regular budget funding, with reference to paragraph 30, to support the work of the section, including the management of the electronic databases, monitoring of agreed periods of aircraft non-availability due to maintenance and/or aircrew sickness and that valid maintenance/medical release certificates are provided, as well as the monitoring and verification of aviation fuel consumption.
Transport Unit:
Abolishment of one post of Vehicle Technician (Local level), as it has been determined that the functions can be effectively covered by the other posts within the Unit; and
Redeployment of one post of Vehicle Technician (Local level) to Kandahar field office to support operational requirements.
Property Management Unit: Abolishment of one post of Administrative Assistant (Local level) following a review of the workload;
Medical, Staff Counselling and Welfare Section:

Establishment of two positions of Paramedic (international United Nations Volunteer), costed at 30 per cent cost of the full cost, representing UNAMA’s contribution in line with the current cost-sharing arrangement, to enhance the capacity support to the Medical Officer (P-3) and to provide medical coverage including basic consultations, emergency triage and referrals; and

Redeployment of one position of Paramedic (international United Nations Volunteer) to the Bamyan field office to provide capacity support to the Medical Emergency Response Team in line with operational requirements.

General Supply and Fuel Unit: Conversion of one position of Finance Assistant (national United Nations Volunteer) from extrabudgetary resources to regular budget funding, with reference to paragraph 30, to support the Unit in financial management;
Field offices in regions and provinces

The field offices will continue to drive mandate implementation at the subnational level through the building of effective working relationships with the de facto authorities to facilitate an enabling environment for mandate and programme implementation and to strengthen the coherence of United Nations activities.

The Mission currently maintains six regional offices, located in Balkh (Mazar-e Sharif), Kabul, Kandahar, Herat, Nangarhar (Jalalabad) and Paktiya (Gardez), and five provincial offices, located in Badakhshan (Faizabad), Baghlan (Pul-e Khumri), Bamyan, Faryab (Maymana), and Kunduz.
The Heads of Office have a direct reporting line to the Chief of Staff.
For 2026, it is proposed that the number of provincial offices be reduced from five to three with the closure of the provincial office in Maimana and Pul-e Khumri.

children.text: Changes to the staffing structure of regional and provincial offices are proposed in the context of as reference in table 21 above:

The closure of field radio security operations centres resulting in the abolishment of 21  Field Radio Operators (Local level) and the redeployment of 17 Field Radio Operators (Local level) posts (two from each of the five regional offices, and seven from the provincial offices: Bamyan (2); Maimana (1); Faizabad (1) Pul-e-Khumri (1); and Kunduz(2)), to the Security Section to constitute the Remote Security Operations Center;

The closure of Pul-e-Khumri and Maimana field offices, resulting in the abolishment of 19 posts, the redeployment of 14 posts and the reassignment of six posts. With the closure of these offices, the Mazar regional office will now serve as the hub for the Northern region. The redeployed capacities from the two field offices will ensure continuing delivery on the mandate in the areas, through the conduct of daily monitoring of developments, ongoing engagement with interlocuters and stakeholders, and undertaking regular field visits and outreach, as required.

A review of mission support capacities in the field offices, which identified that some ICT and security related functions currently at the National Professional Officer level have evolved and can be effectively carried out with a lower-level skill set. To this end, it is proposed that nine National Professional Officer posts, consisting of five posts of Associate Information Systems Officer and four posts of Assistant Security Officer be abolished, and nine Local level posts consisting of five Information Systems Assistant and four Field Security Assistant posts, respectively, be established in their stead;
In addition to the above, the following changes in the UNAMA regional offices are also proposed for 2026:
(a)	Kabul:

Reassignment of two posts to the Security Section, comprising: one post of Security Coordination Officer (P-3) as Administrative Officer (P-3) to reflect adjustments to the roles and responsibilities currently undertaken by the post in view of the need to have dedicated administrative capacity at the appropriate level; and one post of Fire Safety Officer (Field Service) as Security Officer (Field Service) in the Security Investigations Unit to provide critical support to security investigation and incident response.

Reassignment of one post of Associate Information Systems Officer (National Professional Officer) as Assistant Programme Management Officer (National Professional Officer) from the Field Technology Section to support the mine action programme at the central regional level.
Redeployment of one post of Field Security Guard (Local level) to the Security Section; and
Redeployment of one post of Human Rights Assistant (Local level) to the Human Rights Service.
(b)	Kandahar:

Abolishment of one post of Information Systems Assistant (Field Service), with the functions to be effectively discharged by the existing national staff, with remote technical support from Kabul, as required;

Reassignment of one post of Associate Judicial Affairs Officer (National Professional Officer) from the Political Affairs Service in Kabul as Assistant Programme Management Officer (National Professional Officer) to support the mine action programme at the regional level;
Redeployment of one post of Vehicle Technician (Local level) from the Transport Unit to support the increase in road movements; and

Conversion of one position of Associate Political Affairs Officer (national United Nations Volunteer) with reference to paragraph 30, to provide political analysis and support in the monitoring of provincial and district level developments.
(c)	Herat:
Redeployment of one position of Security Logistics Officer (international United Nations Volunteer) to the Security Section.
(d)	Mazar-e Sharif:

Redeployment of 11 posts, namely one Associate Political Affairs Officer (National Professional Officer), one Assistant Human Rights Officers (National Professional Officer), two Political Affairs Assistants (Local level) and two Drivers (Local level) from Pul-e-Khumri field office, and one Associate Political Affairs Officer (National Professional Officer), one Assistant Human Rights Officers (National Professional Officer), one Human Rights Assistant (Local level) and two Drivers (Local level) from Maimana field office, to provide the requisite capacity of the Office which will now serve as a regional hub for the Northern region, which will continue to service the areas following the closure of  both field offices; and

Establishment of one post of Public Information Assistant (Local level) to support the strategic communications work, including supporting outreach, good offices and confidence-building measures between the de facto authorities and other stakeholders. This post will support the Faryab and Pul-e-Khumri strategic communication work.
(e)	Jalalabad:

Abolishment of one post of Information Systems Assistant (Field Service) following a review of the workload of Office, with functions of the position could be effectively discharged by the existing national staff, with remote technical support from Kabul, as required;
Redeployment of one post of Security Officer (Field Service) to Bamyan field office to enhance security capacity in line with operational requirements; and

Reassignment of one post of Assistant Political Affairs Officer (National Professional Officer) as Assistant Programme Management Officer (National Professional Officer) from Pul-e-Khumri field office to provide critical mine action capacity in the Eastern region.
(f)	Gardez:

Reassignment of one position of Associate Political Affairs Officer (national United Nations Volunteer) from Maimana field office as Assistant Human Rights Officer (national United Nations Volunteer) to address the gap in human rights expertise in the Office.

Consolidated Kuwait Office – Table 23 – Staffing requirements: Consolidated Kuwait Office
The Consolidated Kuwait Office comprises two components:

(a)	UNAMA Support Office in Kuwait, which includes one mission staff located in Kuwait, undertakes support functions that are not related to the Kuwait Joint Support Office, namely the post of Chief of Section, Conduct and Discipline (P-5), reporting directly to the Chief of Staff. For 2026, in view of the planned closure of KJSO, it is proposed to redeploy the position from Kuwait to Kabul.

(b)	Kuwait Joint Support Office, which provides transactional administrative services related to finance and human resources to UNAMA, UNAMI and other missions in the Middle East, Asia, Europe and the Americas. UNAMA contributes 38 posts (1 P-5, 1 P-4, 2 P-3, 1 P-2, 14 Field Service and 19 Local level) funded directly from the mission’s budget.
The UNAMA Support Office in Kuwait and the Kuwait Joint Support Office are co-located within the premises occupied by UNAMI in Kuwait City.

In its resolution 79/258, the General Assembly endorsed the recommendation of the ACABQ to review the role of the KJSO in view of the upcoming drawdown of UNAMI.  In this context, the Department of Operational Support conducted a review of the KJSO that focused on ensuring that the 16 peace operations that are currently supported by the KJSO could continue to receive shared services with efficiency, interoperability, responsiveness, and operational continuity after the termination of the mandate for UNAMI at the end of 2025. In this regard, the Secretariat intends to transition the peace operations currently supported by the KJSO, to the RSCE by the end of the UNAMI liquidation process which is anticipated to end in September 2026, leading to the abolishment of the existing 38 UNAMA funded posts, effective 1 October 2026. The financial resources for these posts are only provided for 9 months in the 2026 proposed budget for UNAMA.

5.	Extrabudgetary resources
(a)	Voluntary contributions
In 2025, voluntary contributions in the amount of $2,959,300 are projected to be utilized, comprising the following funding sources:

$200,700 through the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs to support the national female youth United Nations Volunteers programme. The programme’s objective is in line with the Mission’s mandate and contributes to advancing mandate implementation, including inclusive governance, respect for human rights, and peacebuilding with reinforced local capacities, and to good practices across the range of mandated activities and operations;

$2,758,600 under the Mission’s trust fund are being utilized to provide for ten posts (1 P-5, 2 P-4, 6 P-3 and 1 FS), and operational costs to support climate change, aactivities in local peace initiatives and political engagement and meetings with regional governments, and the advancement of international engagement on Afghanistan in a more coherent, coordinated, and structured manner in line with the recommendations of the Independent Assessment on Afghanistan (S/2023/856).

In 2026, voluntary contributions in the estimated amount of $1,429,400 are projected to be utilized under the Mission’s trust fund to continue to provide for five P-3 posts for 12 months, and another four posts (1 P-5, 1 P-4, 1 P-3 and 1FS) for two months.

The decrease in the estimates projected for 2026 compared with the estimates of 2025 reflects the duration of the commitments made by the respective donors under existing agreements. In addition, the NUNV positions are proposed to be converted to regular budget.
(b)	Cost recovery

In 2025, resources in the amount of $23,500,000 are estimated to be received from United Nations agencies, funds and programmes and other entities through the cost recovery mechanism, for services provided by the Mission to these entities, including co-location in Mission compounds and medical services throughout Afghanistan. These cost recovery resources will be utilized to provide for the staff costs of five posts (1 P-3 and 4 Field Service) and for medical-related requirements, including medical personnel and supplies, as well as the costs associated with maintaining United Nations compounds, including security services, rent, utilities and maintenance services. Such resources will complement regular budget resources of the Mission.

For 2026, resources in the amount of $23,500,000 are estimated to be received from United Nations agencies, funds and programmes. These estimates are based on existing clients and cost shared allocations and does not take into account any possible substantial reductions in the number, size and funding ability of the entities, which could translate to lower collections and higher cost-shared portion costs for UNAMA and the other entities who would remain under the existing collocation arrangements.

Annex – Summary of follow-up action taken to implement the decisions and requests of the General Assembly in its resolutions 79/258, including the requests and recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions endorsed by the Assembly

table_content.text: Action taken to implement the recommendation
Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (A/78/7/Add.5)

The Advisory Committee expresses its concern about the high number of vacant posts and trusts that the Mission will fill all vacant posts, including long-vacant ones, as soon as possible and will provide an update on the recruitment status of all vacant posts to the General Assembly at the time of its consideration of the present report and in the next budget submission (para. 24).

As at 30 March 2025, the Mission had 133 vacant posts, including 10 posts which had been vacant for 24 months or longer. The increase in the number of vacant posts is directly a result of the mission-level recruitment freeze implemented in 2024 as part of austerity measures to manage the liquidity challenges, which has necessitated that more posts remain vacant than those required for mandate implementation, and for which the Mission has capacity to fill expeditiously. A list of vacant posts for over two years, including information on the recruitment status, is provided in the supplementary information to the present report.

Mindful of the upcoming drawdown of UNAMI, the Advisory Committee trusts that the Secretary-General will conduct the necessary review of the Kuwait Joint Support Office and include his proposals for the consideration of the General Assembly in the context of his next proposed programme budget submission (para 39)

In 2024, the Department of Operational Support conducted a review of KJSO determine how the peace operations it currently supports can continue to receive sustainable location independent support services that deliver the benefits of efficiency, interoperability, responsiveness, and operational continuity, through the transition of UNAMI in 2025, its liquidation in 2026, and beyond. In this regard, the Secretariat intends to transition the peace operations supported by the KJSO, to the RSCE by the end of the UNAMI liquidation process, leading to the abolishment of all SPM funded posts. Details on the transition plan are presented in the context of the Chapeau report A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.1.

The Advisory Committee, noting the information provided on the cost comparison between flights provided by the United Nations Humanitarian Air Service and those provided by UNAMA, considers that the most effective and economical ways of cooperation should be further explored and trusts that an update on the related impact on requirements under air operations will be provided in the context of the next budget submission (para. 45).

The Aviation and Movement Control Section in UNAMA continues to utilize the services of United Nations Humanitarian Air Service (UNHAS/WFP) on a regular basis.
The Mission carefully analyses each request for air transportation and takes a decision on whether to task its aircraft or transport passengers and/or cargo with regular UNHAS flights. The seat price which UNHAS offers on its regular flights allows the Mission to use UNHAS services as required and to plan for the reduced number of non-guaranteed flight hours and corresponding reduced amount of aviation fuel. The Mission actively seeks opportunities for cost-sharing with UNHAS, for example, from collocated use of UN Air Terminals. The Mission has an MOU on Cooperation in Air Operations with UNHAS and supports UNHAS requests for air transportation on a cost reimbursement basis. Further opportunities for cooperation are explored and will be considered in the 2027 aviation budget proposal. 
It is however important to consider that UNAMA has only one aircraft to assure duty of care and routine transportation needs of mission personnel deployed in 11 locations around Afghanistan.  At the same time UNHAS, faced with substantially reduced donor funding, recently reduced its fleet of aircraft from 7 to 3, including the loss of the last remaining helicopter which could operate to locations that cannot be served by fixed-wing aircraft, including response to critical medical emergencies which could occur in remote locations. In view of the downsizing of UNHAS air fleet, higher utilization of the Mission’s aircraft is anticipated in 2026, which has been factored into the budgeted flight hours.
